awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Variation in Island Adaptations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the origins and development of island subsistence-based economies. In this dissertation proposal a case study is presented in which two Atlantic islands were likely colonized multiple times by more than one cultural group. The islands also have varying environmental characteristics and human subsistence adaptations. The archaeological study of ancient islanders reveals novel information regarding the many ways in which humans adapt and prosper, as islands present often limited, marginal, and vulnerable landscapes. Research on one island shows the arrival of Iron Age peoples who brought with them grains, herding animals, and other cultural elements. In addition, recent excavations on the other revealed a Roman factory where marine gastropods, Stramonita haemastoma, were exploited for commercial purposes to obtain the highly prized royal purple dye. These findings may suggest that the human settlement occurred due to the expansion of ancient seafaring trading networks with the intent to exploit coastal natural resources. Archaeology confirms the islands to have been a nexus of cultural exchange and diversity.

Evidence from ancient material culture, linguistics, and genetics suggest the presence of a heterogenous sociopolitical and economic landscape in the archipelago; however, there is little scholarly consensus as to who exactly peopled the islands and why. A major obstacle to answering these questions is the deficit of reliable chronologies for the entire region – a problem that will be tackled in this current research by developing a series of radiocarbon chronologies. The project will use stable isotope ratios of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and strontium coupled with ancient DNA markers from archaeological human remains to better understand local adaptive strategies, social organization, and landscape management methods. The research will address unresolved questions such as the role of coastal resources in the aboriginal economies. Through exploring diet and mobility, researchers will deepen into the issue of understanding aboriginal modes of production within such culturally diverse island communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Through this project, I have obtained stable isotope results from d13C, d15N, d18O, and 87Sr/86Sr from archaeological human skeletal remains from pre-Hispanic aboriginals of the Canary Islands. Furthermore, I have obtained a new set of radiocarbon (14C) chronologies from the skeletal remains where isotopic analyses were done. The following sites from Tenerife Island have been dated and uncalibrated results in BP (2s) as follows: Montaña Guerra from 1380 to 1290; Pico Yeje from 1665 to 955; Cruz de las Ánimas from 1210 to 590; Hoya Fría from 1285 to 645; Majagora from 1255 to 990; Risco del Perro from 1275 to 875. From Gran Canaria Island, the site of Lomo Maspalomas necropolis (LM) yielded two dates: 530 and 470 BP.

This study has also provided insights into the paleodietary patterns of aboriginal Guanche (Tenerife locals) and the aboriginal groups residing in LM. Specifically, I was able to show that regional distinctions exist in the d15N profiles of ancient Guanches in which the south is significantly enriched in d15N values compared to some northern settlements and chiefdoms. Furthermore, I showed that it is possible to discern differences in dietary patterns from childhood to adulthood using d13C from the mineral portion of bone and teeth (d13Cap). This was valuable for LM, the only site with non-comingled skeletal remains, because I was able to match teeth and bone values to the same person and therefore provide information on different life stages by individual. The most characteristic result is that users of the LM necropolis consumed copious amounts of marine foods during adulthood compared to childhood because the teeth of individuals showed depleted values of d13Cap compared to the bone. Such a shift suggests that a food source with greater levels of 13C was consumed, and since ancient islanders in this region did not consume C4 plants, the plausible explanation is an increased reliance on fish and shellfish. This is also supported by a shift to higher 87Sr/86Sr values from teeth to bone among the LM population. Strontium isotopic values from the ocean are enriched compared to the biologically available (bioavailable) terrestrial 87Sr/86Sr signatures that I have measured in this project. This shift to heavier 87Sr/86Sr values from childhood to adulthood supports the inclusion of marine products into the diet.

On the topic of 87Sr/86Sr values, I was able to show that all the human individuals measured in the project were of local insular origin. This was accomplished thanks to providing a new 87Sr/86Sr bioavailable baseline for Gran Canaria and Tenerife as an outcome of this project. Furthermore, I have presented new d18O values from the carbonate portion of bone thus providing a new scale to measure locality among ancient Canary populations. At this stage, it is difficult to provide a holistic interpretation of human values because a robust baseline for d18O needs to be assembled. In any case, by measuring 17 zooarchaeological remains from Gran Canaria and Tenerife, I have preliminarily shown that there might be an enrichment of d18O values among ovicaprids from coastal areas. I have also shown that samples of archaeological fauna from the southern region of Gran Canaria, which is more arid, have enriched 18O results from those in the north. Finally, by comparing previously published converted d18O data from Gran Canaria to the data I have obtained from Tenerife and LM, significant differences exist between the two islands. I suggest this issue is worth studying further as we try to understand inter-island prehistoric mobility better.


Last Modified: 11/03/2023
Modified by: Paloma Cuello Del Pozo
